entry.title: Mathmetical Analysis
entry.content:
0. Real Number Theory

construction of real number set

Dedekind cuts \(\mathbb{R}\) is all \(\alpha\) such that:

  • \(\alpha eq\varnothing\) and \(\alpha eq\mathbb{Q}\)
  • \( orall p\in\alpha, orallq\in\mathbb{Q},(q<p o q\in\mathbb{Q})\)
  • \( orall p\in\alpha,\existsr\in\alpha,(p<r)\)

define the order on \(\mathbb{R}\):\((\mathbb{R},\leq)\) define theoperator on \(\mathbb{R}\): \((\mathbb{R},+, imes)\)

Cauchy sequence

density \( orallx_1,x_2\in\mathbb{R},\existsx\in\mathbb{R},(x_1<x<x_2)\)

Completeness

the completeness axiom of the reals - every nonemptysubset of real numbers that is bounded above has a supremum - any Cauchysequence converges

1. Limit Theory

Definition of Limits

Limits of Sequences

Set an infinite sequence \(\{x_n\}\), if: \[\exists L, orall\epsilon>0,\existsN\in\mathbb{N}, orall n,(n>N o\lvert x_n-L vert<\epsilon) ag1\] we say that it converge to \(L\), which is denoted as \(\lim_{n o\infty}x_n=L\)

\[ orall G>0,\exists N\in\mathbb{N}, orall n,(n>N o x_n>G) ag2\] we say that itis disvergent, which is denoted as \(\lim_{n o\infty}x_n=\infty\)

Limits of Functions

Set a function \(f(x)\), suppose\(\mathring{U}(x_0)\subseteq D_f\), if:\[\existsL, orall\epsilon>0,\exists\delta>0 , orall x,(\lvert x-x_0 vert<\delta o \lvert f(x)-L vert<\epsilon) ag1\] wesay that it converge to \(L\), which isdenoted as \(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L\)

\[\exists L, orall\epsilon>0,\existsG\in R , orall x,(x>G o \lvert f(x)-L vert<\epsilon) ag2\] we say that it converge to \(L\), which is denoted as \(\lim_{x o\infty}f(x)=L\)

\[ orall K>0,\exists\delta>0, orall x,(\lvert x-x_0 vert<\delta o f(x)>K) ag3\] wesay that it is disvergent, which is denoted as \(\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=\infty\)

\[ orall K>0,\exists G>0, orallx,(x>G o f(x)>K) ag4\] we say that it is disvergent,which is denoted as \(\lim_{x o\infty}f(x)=\infty\)

One-sided Limits

  • left-sided limit: \(\lim_{x ox_0^+}f(x)\)
  • right-sided limit: \(\lim_{x ox_0^-}f(x)\)

Relationship

subsequence: \(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L \leftrightarrow orall \{x_{n_k}\}(\lim_{k o\infty}x_{n_k}=L)\)

Heine theorem \[\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L\iff orall\{x_n\},(\lim_{n o\infty}x_n=x_0 o\lim_{n o\infty}f(x_n)=L)\]

Applying Limits

Properties of Limits

  • uniqueness of limit(唯一性)
    • \((\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L_1)\wedge(\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=L_2) o (L_1=L_2)\)
  • boundedness of limit(有界性)
    • \((\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=L) o(\existsM, orall x\in\mathring{U}(x_0,\delta),(M\geq x))\)
  • locally sign-preserving property(保号性)
    • \((\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L)\wedge(L<t) o(\exists\delta>0, orallx\in\mathring{U}(x_0,\delta),(x<t))\)
  • squeeze theorem(迫敛性)
    • if \(\lim_{x o x_0}g(x)=\lim_{x ox_0}h(x)=L\) and \( orallx\in\mathring{U}(x_0),(g(x)\leq f(x)\leq h(x))\), then \(\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=L\)

Criteria for the Existenceof Limits

Squeeze Theorem: \[g_1(x)\leq f(x) \leq g_2(x)\wedge\lim _{x ox_0}g_1(x)=\lim _{x o x_0}g_2(x)=L o\lim _{x o x_0}f(x)=L\]an important limit: \(\lim _{x o0}\cfrac{\sin x}{x}=1\)

Proof: \(x\in(0, rac\pi2) o\sinx<x< an x o\cos x<\cfrac{\sin x}{x}<1\)

Monotone Convergence Theorem: If a function orsequence of real numbers is monotonic and bounded, then it definitelyhas a limit an important limit: \(\lim _{x o\infty}(1+\cfrac 1x)^x=e\)

Proof:

Cauchy principle of convergence: a given \(\{a_n\}\) is called Cauchy sequence if:\[ orall\epsilon>0,\existsN\in\mathbb{N}, orall i,j>N,(|a_i-a_j|<\epsilon)\] aCauchy sequence converge

Infinitesimal

Infinitesimals

if ==\(\lim \alpha(x)=0\)==, then wecall \(\alpha(x)\) is the infinitesimalquantity in this limit process

a theorem that relate limits and infinitesimal quantities: \[\lim f(x)=L\ifff(x)+\alpha(x)=L,\lim\alpha(x)=0\]

properties of infinitesimal: \(\limC\cdot\alpha=0\) based on infinitesimals, we can deduce thefour arithmetic rules of limits

Order of infinitesimals

sometimes the four arithmetic rules of limits fail, we call theselimits indeterminate: examples: \(\cfrac00,\cfrac\infty\infty,0\cdot\infty,\infty-\infty,\infty^0,0^0,(1+0)^\infty\)Fortunately, all above can be reduced to the the form of \(\cfrac 00\)

  • Higher-order infinitesimal: \(\lim\cfrac eta\alpha=0\) , denoted as==\( eta=o(\alpha)\)==
  • Lower-order infinitesimal: \(\lim \cfrac eta \alpha=\infty\) , denoted as ==\(\alpha=o( eta)\)==
  • Same-order infinitesimals: \(\lim \cfrac eta \alpha=c\) , denoted as ==\( eta\sim c\alpha\)==
  • \(k\)th-order infinitesimal: \(\lim \cfrac eta {\alpha^k}=c\) , denotedas ==\( eta\sim c\alpha^k\)==
  • Equivalent infinitesimal: \(\lim \cfrac eta \alpha=1\) , denoted as==\( eta\sim\alpha\)==

Among all, Equivalent infinitesimal is the most important one, forthe reason that we use them to simplify equations very often, which isbased on the equivalent infinitesimal substitution theorems: If \(\alpha\sim eta\) , then \(\lim \alpha f(x)=\lim eta f(x)\)

after we determine a Reference infinitesimal, often\(x\), we look for \(k\) such that \(f(x)=cx^k+o(x^k)\), then \(cx^k\) is called Infinitesimalprincipal

Useful EquivalentInfinitesimal

when \(x o0\):

  • \(x\sim\sin x\sim an x\)
  • \(\cos x\sim 1- rac12x^2\)
  • \(x\sim e^x-1\sim\ln (x+1)\)
  • \((1+x)^\mu-1\sim\mu x\)

hint: don't forget when \(u(x) o0\), all \(x\) above can bereplaced with \(u(x)\) integrally

Continuity

Definition of Continuity

Continuity at one point set a function \(f(x)\), suppose \(\mathring{U}(x_0)\subseteq D_f\), if limitbelow exists: \[\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=f(x_0)\] then we said \(f(x)\) is continuous at \(x_0\)

one-sided continuity:

  • left-sided continuity: \(\lim_{x ox_0^+}f(x)= f(x_0)\)
  • right-sided continuity: \(\lim_{x ox_0^-}f(x)= f(x_0)\)

Continuity on an interval If \( orall x_0\in (a,b),(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=f(x_0))\) and \(\lim_{x oa^+}f(x)= f(a)\) , we say that \(f(x)\) is continuious on \([a,b)\) , denoted as \(f(x)\in C[a,b)\) distinction between openinterval & closed interval

Discontinuity

  • Removable Discontinuity: \(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L\) but \(L eqx_0\)
  • Jump Discontinuity: \(\lim_{x ox_0^+}f(x) eq\lim_{x o x_0^-}f(x)\)
  • Infinite Discontinuity: \(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=\infty\)
  • Oscillatory Discontinuity: \(\lim_{x o0}\sin rac 1x\)

uniform continuity

Properties of continuousfunction

  • continuous functions remain continuous after basic arithmeticoperations, composite operations, and inverse operations

  • elementary functions are all continuous

  • continuous function on a closed interval

    • has both minimum and maximum
    • intermediate value thm \[f(x)\inC[a,b] o orall c\in(f(a),f(b)),\exists\xi\in(a,b),(c=f(\xi))\]

2. Derivative & Differential

Derivative

Definition of Derivative

set a function \(f(x)\), suppose\(\mathring{U}(x_0)\subseteq D_f\), thederivative of \(f(x)\) at \(x_0\) is defined as: \[f'(x_0)=\lim _{\Delta x o 0}\cfrac{f(x_0+\Delta x)-f(x_0)}{\Delta x}\] if the limit exists, we saythat \(f(x)\) is derivable at \(x_0\)

derivative function of \(f(x)\) is denoted as \(f'(x)\) and it is a function such that:\[ orall x\in D_f,(f'(x)=\lim _{\Deltax o 0}\cfrac {f(x_0+\Delta x)-f(x_0)}{\Delta x})\]

one-sided derivative:

  • right-sided derivative: \(f'_+(x)\)
  • left-sided derivative: \(f'_-(x)\)

Derivability

\(f\) is continuous \(\Rightarrow\) \(f\) is derivable continue but notderivable: two cases where derivative limit does not exist

  • cusp: \(f'_+(x) eqf'_-(x)\)
  • vertical: \(f'(x)=\infty\)

derivative of a derivable function is continue orhas oscillatory discontinuity

Derivation

Derivation

\((c_1u+c_2v)'=c_1u'+c_2v'\)\((uv)'=u'v+uv'\)

derivatives of elementary functions

  • power function
  • exponential function \(\lim _{x o\infty}(1+\cfrac 1x)^x=e\)
  • logarithmic function \(\lim _{x o\infty}(1+\cfrac 1x)^x=e\)
  • trigonometric function \(\lim _{x o0}\cfrac{\sin x}{x}=1\)
  • inverse trigonometric function \(\lim _{x o 0}\cfrac{\sin x}{x}=1\)

inverse function derivation rule: \[\cfrac {\mathrm{d}f(x)}{\mathrm{d}x}=\cfrac1{\cfrac {\mathrm{d}f^{-1}(f(x))}{\mathrm{d}f(x)}}\]composed function derivation rule, a.k.a. chain rule:\[\cfrac{\mathrm{d}f(g(x))}{\mathrm{d}x}=\cfrac{\mathrm{d}f(g(x))}{\mathrm{d}g(x)}\cfrac{\mathrm{d}g(x)}{\mathrm{d}x}\] parameterized equationderivation suppose \(x=\phi (t),y=\psi (t)\), then \(\cfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=\cfrac {\psi '(t)}{\phi'(t)}\) \(\cfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=\lim_{\Deltax o0}\cfrac{y(x+\Delta x)-y(x)}{\Delta x}=\lim_{\Delta t o0}\cfrac{\psi(t+\Delta t)-\psi(t)}{\phi(t+\Deltat)-\phi(t)}\)

High Ordered Derivative

high ordered derivative is denoted as \[f^{(n)}(x)=\cfrac{\mathrm{d}^n}{\mathrm{d}x^n}f(x)\] Leibnizformula \[(uv)^{(n)}=\sum_{k=0}^n{n\choosek}u^{(k)}v^{(n-k)}\]

high ordered derivative of some elementary functions:

  • \((x^m)^{(n)}=m(m-1)\cdots(m-n+1)x^{m-n}\)
  • \((a^x)^{(n)}=a^x(\ln a)^n\)
  • \((\lnx)^{(n)}=(-1)^{n-1}\cfrac{(n-1)!}{x^n}\)
  • \((\sinx)^{(n)}=\sin(x+ rac{n\pi}{2})\)
  • \((\cosx)^{(n)}=\cos(x+ rac{n\pi}{2})\)

to solve high ordered derivative:

  • reduce to the elementary functions by changing the form into sum ofseveral terms
  • use Leibniz formula
  • use Taylor formula
  • mathmatical induction

Application of Derivative

Monotonicity & Convexity

suppose \(f\in C[a,b]\) and \(f\in D(a,b)\)

  • stationary point(驻点): \(f'(x_0)=0\)
  • minimal & maximal(极值点): \( orall x\in\mathring{U}(x_0),(f(x_0)<f(x))\) and \(f'(x_0)=0\)
  • minimum & maximum(最值点): two ends or aminimal

monotonicity \( orallx\in I,(f'(x)\leq 0)\iff orall x_1\leq x_2\in I,(f(x_1)\geqf(x_2))\), or \(f\) ismonotonically decreasing

Proof: \(\Leftarrow\): use thedefinition of derivative \(\Rightarrow\): use differential mean valuetheorem

concavity and convexity \( orall x\in I,(f''(x)< 0)\iff orallx_1\leq x_2\in I,(f(\cfrac {x_1+x_2}2) <\cfrac{f(x_1)+f(x_2)}2)\), or \(f\) is concave \( orall x\in I,(f''(x)> 0)\iff orallx_1\leq x_2\in I,(f(\cfrac {x_1+x_2}2) >\cfrac{f(x_1)+f(x_2)}2)\), or \(f\) is convex

proof

Curvature

differential of arc: \(\mathrm{d}s=\sqrt{(\mathrm{d}x)^2+(\mathrm{d}y)^2}=\sqrt{1+y'^2}\mathrm{d}x\) curvature: \(K=\cfrac{\mathrm{d} heta}{\mathrm{d}s}=\cfrac{\cfrac{y''}{y'^2+1}\mathrm{d}x}{\sqrt{1+y'^2}\mathrm{d}x}=\cfrac {y''}{(1+y'^2)^{ rac32}}\) circle of curvature

  • radius of curvature: \( ho =\cfrac 1K\)
  • centre of curvature: \(D(x-\cfrac{y'(1+y'^2)}{y''},y+\cfrac{1+y'^2}{y''})\)

write the locus of the center of curvature of \(f(x)\) as \(g(x)\), then \(g(x)\) is theevolute(渐屈线) of \(f(x)\) and \(f(x)\) is the involute(渐伸线) of \(g(x)\)

Approximate solution ofthe equation

To solve the equation \(f(x)=0\),first find out the isolation interval \([a,b]\), then:

  • 二分法
    • \(x_{n+1}=x_n+x_{n-1}\)
  • 切线法
    • \(x_{n+1}=x_n-\cfrac{f(x_n)}{f'(x_n)}\)
  • 割线法
    • \(x_{n+1}=x_n-\cfrac{x_n-x_{n-1}}{f(x_n)-f(x_{n-1})}f(x_n)\)

Differential

\(\mathrm{d}y\) is called thedifferential main part of \(\Delta y\),where - \(\Delta y=y(x+\Delta x)-y(x)=A\Deltax+o(\Delta x)\) - \(\mathrm{d}y=\lim_{\Delta x o 0}y(x+\Deltax)-y(x)=A\Delta x\) - \(\mathrm{d}x=\Delta x\)

from the definition, we have \[A=f'(x)\]

use differential to make approximate calculation \(y(x_0+\Delta x)=y(x_0)+\Delta y\approxy(x_0)+f'(x_0)\Delta x\)

3. Taylor Formula

Differential Mean ValueTheorem

Differential Mean Value Theorem reflects the relationship betweenfunctions and derivatives

Fermat's Extreme Value Theorem Suppose \(f\in D\mathring{U}(x_0)\) and \( orall x\in \mathring{U}(x_0), igg(f(x_0)\leqf(x) igg)\) , than \(f'(x_0)=0\)

Rolle mean value theorem Suppose \(f\in C[a,b]\), \(f\in D(a,b)\), and \(f(a)=f(b)\), then: \[\exists\xi\in(a,b), igg(f'(\xi)=0 igg)\]>[!note] Proof >if \(f\) is aconstant function, then \( orallx\in(a,b),(f'(x)=0)\) >otherwise, it has an extremum, thenuse Fermat Thm

Lagrange mean value theorem Suppose \( ig(f,g\in C[a,b] ig)\wedge ig(f,g\inC^1(a,b) ig)\), then: \[\exists \xi\in (a,b), igg(f'(\xi)=\cfrac {f(a)-f(b)}{a-b} igg)\]>[!note] Proof >constructing auxiliary function\(\phi (x)=f(x)-\cfrac{f(a)-f(b)}{a-b}x\) >according to Rolle's Thm, \(\exists\xi\in(a,b), igg(\phi'(\xi)=0 igg)\)

Cauchy mean value theorem Suppose \( ig(f,g\in C[a,b] ig)\wedge ig(f,g\inC^1(a,b) ig)\wedge ig(g'(x) eq0 ig)\), then: \[\exists\xi\in(a,b), igg(\cfrac{f'(\xi)}{g'(\xi)}=\cfrac{f(a)-f(b)}{g(a)-g(b)} igg)\]

[!note] Proof constructing auxiliary function \(\phi (x)=f(x)-\cfrac{f(a)-f(b)}{g(a)-g(b)}g(x)\) according to Lagrangemean value Thm, \(\exists\xi\in(a,b), igg(\phi'(\xi)=0 igg)\)

L'Hôpital's rule

Suppose \( ig(f,g\inC^1\mathring{U}(x_0,\delta) ig)\wedge ig(\lim _{x o x_0}f(x)=\lim_{x o x_0}{g(x)}=0 ig)\wedge ig(g'(x_0) eq0 ig)\), then:\[\lim _{x o x_0}\cfrac {f(x)}{g(x)}=\lim_{x o x_0}\cfrac {f'(x)}{g'(x)}\]

Proof WLOG let \(f(x_0)=g(x_0)=0\)By Definition of Derivative: \(\lim _{x ox_0}\cfrac {f(x)}{g(x)}=\lim_{x ox_0}\cfrac{\cfrac{f(x)-f(x_0)}{x-x_0}}{\cfrac{g(x)-g(x_0)}{x-x_0}}=\lim_{x o x_0}\cfrac {f'(x)}{g'(x)}\) Use Cauchy mean valuetheorem: \(\exists\xi\in(x,x_0), ig(\cfrac{f'(\xi)}{g'(\xi)}=\cfrac{f(x)-f(x_0)}{g(x)-g(x_0)} ig)\), so \(\lim _{x o x_0}\cfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}=\lim_{\xi o x_0}\cfrac{f'(\xi)}{g'(\xi)}=\lim_{x o x_0}\cfrac {f'(x)}{g'(x)}\)

Taylor Formula

How to approximate a given function \(f(x)\) (in the neighborhood of \(x_0\)) by a n-degree polynomial function\(P_n(x)\) ? Find a polynomial functionsuch that: \(P_n^{(k)}(x_0)=f^{(k)}(x_0)\) so that theremainder \(R_n(x)=f^{(k)}(x_0)-P_n^{(k)}(x_0)=o(x-x_0)^n\)

Proof from the defination of \(P_n(x)\) , \(R_n^{(k)}=0,k\in\{0,1,2,\dots,n\}\) fromL'Hôpital's rule \(\lim_{x ox_0}\cfrac{R_n(x)}{(x-x_0)^{n}}=0\)

Suppose \(f(x)\in C^n\)Taylor Formula: \[f(x)=\sum_{k=0}^n\cfrac{f^{(k)}(x_0)}{k!}(x-x_0)^k+R_n(x)\] PeanoRemainder: \[R_n(x)=o((x-x_0)^n)\] LagrangeRemainder: (need \(f(x)\inC^{n+1}\)) \[R_n(x)=\cfrac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!}(x-x_0)^{n+1}\]

more often then not, we use the equation below: MaclaurinSeries Expansion: \[f(x)=\sum_{k=0}^n\cfrac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}x^k+R_n(x)\] some requently used Maclaurinexpansion listed below:

  • \(e^x=\sum_{k=0}^n\cfrac{x^k}{k!}+o(x^n)\)
  • \(\ln(1+x)=\sum_{k=1}^n\cfrac{(-1)^{k+1}}{k}x^k+o(x^n)\)
  • \(\cfrac1{1-x}=\sum_{k=0}^nx^k+o(x^n)\)
  • \(\cfrac{1}{x+b}=\sum_{k=0}^n\cfrac{(-1)^k}{b^{k+1}}x^k+o(x^n)\)
  • \((1+x)^a=\sum_{k=0}^n{a\choosek}x^k+o(x^n)\)
  • \(\sin x=\sum_{k=0}^n\cfrac{\sin( rac{k\pi}2)}{k!}x^k+o(x^n)\)
  • \(\cosx=\sum_{k=0}^n\cfrac{\cos( rac{k\pi}2)}{k!}x^k+o(x^n)\)
  • \( anx=x+ rac13x^3+ rac2{15}x^5+o(x^5)\)
  • \(\arcsin x=x+ rac16x^3\)
  • \(e=\sum_{k=0}^n{n\choosek}\cfrac1{n^k}=\sum_{k=0}^n\cfrac1{k!}\)

4. Integral

Indefinite Integral

Definition of IndefiniteIntegral

if \(F'(x)=f(x)\), then \(F(x)\) is a primitive of\(f(x)\)

all the primitive of \(f(x)\) iscalled indefinite integral of it, denoted as \(\int f(x)\mathrm{d}x\) \[\int f(x)\mathrm{d}x=F(x)+C\]

Table of Integrals

  • \(\intx^{m}\mathrm{d}x=\cfrac{1}{m+1}x^{m+1}+C\)
  • \(\int\cfrac1x\mathrm{d}x=\ln|x|+C\)
  • \(\int a^x\mathrm{d}x=\cfrac{a^x}{\lna}+C\)
  • \(\int \ln x\mathrm{d}x=x\lnx-x+C\)
  • \(\int\sin x\mathrm{d}x=-\cosx+C\)
  • \(\int\cos x\mathrm{d}x=\sinx+C\)
  • \(\int an x\mathrm{d}x=\ln|\secx|+C\)
  • \(\int\sec x\mathrm{d}x=\ln|\sec x+ anx|+C\)
  • \(\int\sec^2x\mathrm{d}x=\tanx+C\)
  • \(\int\csc^2x\mathrm{d}x=-\cotx+C\)
  • \(\int\cfrac{\mathrm{d}x}{x^2+a^2}= rac1a\arctan\cfrac xa+C\)
  • \(\int\cfrac{\mathrm{d}x}{x^2-a^2}= rac1{2a}\ln|\cfrac{x-a}{x+a}|+C\)
  • \(\int\cfrac{\mathrm{d}x}{\sqrt{a^2-x^2}}=\arcsin\cfracxa+C\)
  • \(\int\cfrac{\mathrm{d}x}{\sqrt{x^2+a^2}}=\ln(x+\sqrt{x^2+a^2})+C\)
  • \(\int\cfrac{\mathrm{d}x}{\sqrt{x^2-a^2}}=\ln|x+\sqrt{x^2-a^2}|+C\)

integeral method

integration by substitution \[\int f(x)dx=\int\cfrac{f(x)}{u'(x)}du\] \[\intf(x)dx=\int f(x)x'(t)dt\] integration byparts \[\int uv'dx=uv-\intu'vdx\]

Integeral of rationalfunctions

a rational function can be can be represented as \(R(x)=H(x)+\cfrac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\), \(H(x),P(x),Q(x)\) are polynomials and \(\deg(P)<\deg(Q)\)

use method of indeterminate coefficients \[\cfrac {P(x)}{Q(x)}=\sum\sum_{i=1}^k \cfrac{A_i}{(x-a)^i}+\sum\sum_{i=1}^k \cfrac{B_ix+C_i}{(x^2+bx+c)^i}\]

  • \(I=\int\cfrac{A_k}{(x-a)^k}\mathrm{d}x\)
    • when \(k=1\), \(I=\int\cfrac{A}{x-a}dx=A\ln{\lvert x-a vert}\)
    • when \(k>1\), \(I=\int\cfrac{A}{(x-a)^k}d(x-a)=\cfrac{-A}{(k-1)(x-a)^{k-1}}\)
  • \(I=\int\cfrac{B_kx+C_k}{(x^2+bx+c)^k}\mathrm{d}x=\int\cfrac{m\mathrm{d}(x^2+bx+c)+n\mathrm{d}x}{(x^2+bx+c)^k}=\cfrac{-m}{(k-1)(x^2+bx+c)^{k-1}}+\int\cfrac{n\mathrm{d}t}{(t^2+1)^k}\)
    • when \(k=1\), \(\int\cfrac{\mathrm{d}t}{t^2+1}=\arccost\)
    • when \(k>1\), \(\int\cfrac{\mathrm{d}t}{(t^2+1)^k}=\)

translate into rational functions use substitutionmethod to transition a function into rational function, let \(t= an rac x2\) \[\int R(\sin x,\cos x)\mathrm{d}x=\intR(\cfrac{2t}{1+t^2},\cfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2})\cfrac{2}{1+t^2}\mathrm{d}t\]when it is homogeneous, we use \(t= anx\) \[\int R( an x)\mathrm{d}x=\intR(t)\cfrac{1}{1+t^2}\mathrm{d}t\] rational function with root,let \(t=\sqrt[n]{ rac{ax+b}{cx+d})}\)\[\intR(x,\sqrt[n]{ rac{ax+b}{cx+d})}\mathrm{d}x=\intR( rac{dt^n-b}{-ct^n+a},t)\mathrm{d}( rac{dt^n-b}{-ct^n+a})\]

Riemann Integeral

Defination

we define Riemann Integeral , denoted as \(\int_a^bf(x)\mathrm{d}x\) as: suppose asequence \(\{x_i\}_{i=0}^n\) and \(x_0=a,x_n=b\), and we let \(\Delta x_i=x_i-x_{i-1}\), \(\lambda=\max\{\Delta x_1,\Delta x_2,\cdots,\Deltax_n\}\), \(\xi_i\in[x_{i-1},x_i]\), \(S=\sum_{i=1}^n\Delta x_if(\xi_i)\), then\[\lim_{\lambda o0}S=\int_a^bf(x)\mathrm{d}x\]

Riemannian integrability of \(f(x)\): \(f(x)\inR[a,b]\iff\) the set of

Properties

mean value theorem of integeral \(f(x),g(x)\in C[a,b]\) and \(g(x)\geq0\) \[\exists\xi\in(a,b),\Big(\int_a^bf(x)g(x)\mathrm{d}x=\int_a^bf(\xi)g(x)\mathrm{d}x\Big)\]

Newtom-Leibniz eqution

we are going to explore the connection between determinate integeraland differential

Newtom-Leibniz \[\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\int_a^xf(x)\mathrm{d}x=f(x)\]

Proof: let \(\Phi(x)=\int_a^xf(x)\mathrm{d}x\), then\(\Delta\Phi(x)=\Phi(x+\Deltax)-\Phi(x)=\int_x^{x+\Delta x}f(x)\mathrm{d}x\) \(\Rightarrow\exists\xi\in(x,x+\Deltax),\Big(\int_x^{x+\Delta x}f(x)\mathrm{d}x=f(\xi)\Delta x\Big)\)\(\Rightarrow\Deltax o0,\Big(\int_x^{x+\Delta x}f(x)\mathrm{d}x=f(x)\Delta x\Big)\)\(\Rightarrow\lim_{\Delta x o0}\cfrac{\Phi(x+\Delta x)-\Phi(x)}{\Delta x}=f(x)\)

suppose \(\intf(x)\mathrm{d}x=F(x)+C\), then \[\int_a^bf(x)\mathrm{d}x=F(b)-F(a)\]

Proof: \(F(x)=\Phi(x)+C=\int_a^xf(x)\mathrm{d}x+C\)\(F(a)=\int_a^af(x)\mathrm{d}x+C=C\)\(F(b)=\int_a^bf(x)\mathrm{d}x+C\)

\[\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\int_{\psi(x)}^{\phi(x)}f(t)\mathrm{d}t=f(\phi(x))\phi'(x)-f(\psi(x))\psi'(x)\]

n even \(\int_0^{ rac\pi2}\sin^nx=\cfrac{n-1!!}{n!!} rac\pi2\)n odd \(\int_0^{ rac\pi2}\sin^nx=\cfrac{n-1!!}{n!!}\)

Application of Integral

  • area of two-dimensional figure
    • \(A=\int_a^by\mathrm{d}x\)
    • \(A= rac12\int_\alpha^ eta ho^2\mathrm{d} heta\)
  • volume of a three-dimensional figure whose section area can befigured out
    • \(V=\int_a^bA(x)\mathrm{d}x\)
  • volume of a rotator
    • \(V_x=\pi\int_a^by^2\mathrm{d}x\)\(V_y=\pi\int_a^bx^2\mathrm{d}y\)
  • length of arc
    • \(s=\int_a^b\sqrt{1+y'^2}\mathrm{d}x\)
    • \(s=\int_\alpha^ eta\sqrt{\phi'^2(t)+\psi'^2(t)}\mathrm{d}t\)
    • \(s=\int_\alpha^ eta\sqrt{ ho'^2+ ho^2}\mathrm{d} heta\)
  • area of rotating surface
    • \(A_x=2\pi\int_a^by\sqrt{1+y'^2}\mathrm{d}x\)
    • \(A_x=2\pi\int_a^b\psi(t)\sqrt{\phi'^2(t)+\psi'^2(t)}\mathrm{d}t\)
    • \(A_x=2\pi\int_\alpha^ eta\phi( heta)\sin heta\sqrt{ ho'^2( heta)+ ho^2( heta)}\mathrm{d} heta\)

Improper integral

case 1: integeral interval is unbounded \[\int_a^{+\infty}f(x)\mathrm{d}x=\lim_{x o+\infty}F(x)-F(a)\]

case 2: \(f\) is unbounded at \(\mathring{U}(b)\), where \(b\) is called 瑕点/奇点 \[\int_a^bf(x)\mathrm{d}x=\lim_{x ob^-}F(x)-F(a)\]

convergence test

反常积分审敛法 1.无穷限反常积分审敛 2.无界函数反常积分审敛

entry.title: Set Theory
entry.content:
Set

Notations

  • relashionship of set
    • \(A\subseteq B\iff orall x(x\in A ox\in B)\)
    • \(A=B\iff orall x(x\in A\leftrightarrowx\in B)\)
  • operations of set
    • \(A\cap B=\{ x|x\in A \wedge x\inB\}\)
    • \(A\cup B=\{ x|x\in A \vee x\inB\}\)
    • \(A\setminus B=\{x|x\in A\wedge x otinB\}\)
    • \(A^c=\{x|x otin A\}\)
    • \(A\Delta B=(A\cup B)\setminus(A\capB)\)
    • \( igcap_{i\in I}A_i=\{x| orall i\inI,x\in A_i\}\)
    • \( igcup_{i\in I}A_i=\{x|\exists i\inI,x\in A_i\}\)

Limit of Set

a given sequence of set \(\{A_n\}_{n=1}^\infty\)

  • if \(A_n\subset A_{n+1}\), we saysit is monotone increasing and denote \( igcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n\) as \(\lim_{n o\infty}A_n\)
  • if \(A_n\supset A_{n+1}\), we saysit is monotone decreasing and denote \( igcap_{n=1}^\infty A_n\) as \(\lim_{n o\infty}A_n\)

since \(\{ igcap_{k=n}^\inftyA_k\}_{n=1}^\infty\) is monotone increasing, we define: \[\lim\inf_{n o\infty}A_n= igcup_{n=1}^\infty igcap_{k=n}^\infty A_k\] \(x\in\lim\inf_{n o\infty}A_n\iff\exists n, orallk\geq n,(x\in A_k)\)

since \(\{ igcap_{k=n}^\inftyA_k\}_{n=1}^\infty\) is monotone decreasing, we define \[\lim\sup_{n o\infty}A_n= igcap_{n=1}^\infty igcup_{k=n}^\infty A_k\] \(x\in\lim\sup_{n o\infty}A_n\iff orall n,\existsk\geq n,(x\in A_k)\)

other Structions

n-tuple: \[(x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n)=\{x_1,\{x_1,x_2\},\{x_1,x_2,x_3\},\cdots\}\]Cartesian product \[A imesB=\{(a,b)|a\in A \wedge b\in B\}\] specifically, \(A^4=A imes A imes A imes A\)

Power set the power set of \(S\), denoted as \(\mathscr{P}(S)\), such that \[X\in\mathscr{P}(S)\iff X\subseteq S\]

Partition \(\mathscr{A}\) is a partition of nonemptyset \(X\) if:

  • \( orallA\in\mathscr{A},(A eq\emptyset)\)
  • \( igcup_{A\in\mathscr{A}}A=X\)
  • \( orall A_1,A_2\in X,(A\capB eq\emptyset o A_1=A_2)\)

Mapping

\(f\) is a mapping from \(X\) to \(Y\), denoted as \(f:X o Y\), if:

  • \( orall x\in X,\exists y\inY,\Big((x,y)\in f\Big)\)
  • \( orall x\in X, orall y_1,y_2\inY,\Big((x,y_1)\in f\wedge(x,y_2)\in f o y_1=y_2\Big)\)

\(f\) is a correspondence rulebetween two nonempty set \(X,Y\) andeach \(x\in X\) map to a unique \(y\in Y\), then \(f\) is a mapping from \(X\) to \(Y\) denoted as \(f:X o Y\)

  • domain: \(D=X\)
  • codomain: \(Y\)
  • range: \(R=\{y|y=f(x),x\in D\}\)
  • If \(x\) is an element of \(X\), and \(f(x)=y\), then \(x\) is preimage of \(y\), \(y\)is image of \(x\),denoted as \(x\mapsto y\)

bijection & injection & surjection -injection/one to one: \( orall x_1,x_2\inX,(f(x_1)=f(x_2) o x_1=x_2)\) - surjection/onto: \( orall y\in Y,\exists x \in X,(f(x)=y)\) -bijection: \( orall x_1,x_2\inX,(f(x_1)=f(x_2) o x_1=x_2)\wedge orall y\in Y,\exists x \inX,(f(x)=y)\)

  • function
    • a mapping from number set to number set
  • functional
    • a mapping from function set to number set
  • operator
    • a mapping from function set to function set
  • identity function
    • \(i_X:X o X\) defined by \(i_X(x)=x\)
  • composition
    • \(f:A o B,g:B o C\), then \(g\circ f(x)=g(f(x))\)
    • \(h\circ (g\circ f)=(h\circ g)\circf\)
  • inverse
    • let \(f:X o Y\) a bijection, \(f(x)=y\iff f^{-1}(y)=x\)
    • \(f^{-1}\circ f=i_X\) and \(f\circ f^{-1}=i_Y\)
    • \((f\circ g)^{-1}=g^{-1}\circf^{-1}\)
  • image of \(A\subseteqX\)
    • \(f(A)=\{f(x)|x\in A\}\)
  • inverse images of \(B\subseteq Y\)
    • \(f^{-1}(B)=\{y|f(y)\in B\}\)
  • transformation \(f:X oX\)
    • permutation \(T\)is a transformation and a bijetion
    • identity map \(I:X oX, orall x\in X,(I(x)=x)\)

indicator function suppose \(S\subseteq X\), then \(\chi_S:X o\{0,1\}\) defined by \(\chi_S(x)=0\) if \(x otin S\), and \(\chi_S(x)=1\) if \(x\in S\)

Relation

if \(R\subseteq X^n\), it is calledn-ary relation more often, we discuss binaryrelation

suppose \(R\) is a binary relationon \(X\), it has the followingproperties conditionally:

  • reflexive property
    • \( orall x\in X((x,x)\in R)\)
  • symetric property
    • \((x_1,x_2)\in R o(x_2,x_1)\inR\)
  • antisymetric property
    • \((x_1,x_2)\in R\wedge (x_2,x_1)\in R ox_1=x_2\)
  • strongly antisymetric property
    • \((x_1,x_2)\in R o(x_2,x_1) ot\inR\)
  • transitive property
    • \((x_1,x_2\in R\wedge(x_2,x_3)\inR o(x_1,x_3)\in R)\)
    • EXAMPLE1:"greater than" relation on the set of real numbers istransitive
    • 传递闭包(transitive closure)
      • The transitive closure of \(R\),denoted by \(R^*\),is defined as \(R^*=R igcup\{(x_i,x_j)|\exists x_{k_1}\cdotsx_{k_t}((x_i,x_{k_1}),(x_{k_1},x_{k_2}),\cdots,(x_{k_t},x_j)\inR)\}\)
      • 其实\(R^*\)就是包含\(R\)的具有传递性的最小集合
      • Warshall Algorithm 寻找传递闭包的算法
        • n次循环{找到(a,i)(i,b),add \(A imesB\)}

\(R\) is an equivalence relation ifand only if it is:

  • reflexive
  • symetric
  • transitive

when \(R\) is an equivalencerelation set, we write \((x,y)\in R\)as \(x\sim y\), we also define \(E_x=\{y\in X:x\sim y\}\), calledequivalence class

Order

Preorder

for a given \((X,R)\), \(X\) is a preordered set,a.k.a. quasi-order set, when \(R\)is:

  • irreflexive ? reflexive
  • transitive

Partial Order

for a given \((X,R)\), \(X\) is a partially orderedset, when \(R\) is:

  • reflexive
  • antisymetric
  • transitive

we write \((x,y)\in R\) as \(x\preceq y\), called \(x\) precede \(y\) if \(x\preceqy \wedge x eq y\), they we write it as \(x\prec y\), called \(x\) strictly precede \(y\)

comparability

suppose \(x_1,x_2\in X\) and \(X\) is a partially ordered set, then if\(x_1\preceq x_2\vee x_2\preceq x_1\),we says they are comparable, otherwice, they are uncomparable andwritten as \(x_1||x_2\) trichotomy ofrelations: \[x_1\preceq x_2\vee x_2\preceqx_1\vee x_1||x_2\]

given a partial order set \((X,\preceq)\) and a set \(S\subseteq X\)

  • lower bound & upper bound:
    • if \(\exists m\in X, orall x\inS,(m\preceq x)\), then \(m\) isa lower bound of \(S\)
  • infimum & supremum:
    • if \(l\) is a lower bound of \(S\), and \( orall m,(m\preceq l)\), then \(l\) is an infimum of \(S\)
    • \(l\) is denoted as \(\inf S\)
  • minimal & maximal:
    • if \(\exists m\in S, orall x\inS,(m preceq x)\) , then \(m\)is a minimal of \(S\)
  • minimum & maximum:
    • if \(\exists m\in S, orall x\inS,(m\preceq x)\) then \(m\) is aminimum of \(S\)

Hasse diagram

we say \(x\) is a immediatepredcessor of \(y\) if and only if\[(x\prec y)\wedge( eg\exists z\in X,(x\precz\wedge z\prec y))\] we denote it as \(x\ll y\)

then, we draw a line between two elements if and only if one is animmediate predcessor of the other, this is called Hasse diagram![[Pasted image 20231108153940.png|250]]

Total Order

a partially ordered set \(X\) is atotally ordered set, a.k.a. chain or linear order,when: \[ orall x,y\in X,(x\preceq y\veey\preceq x\vee x=y)\]

\(X\) is a well-orderedset if and only if: \[ orallS\subset X,S eq\emptyset, ig(\exists x\in S, orall y\in S,(x=y\veexRy) ig)\]

Lattice

two equivalentdefinitions of lattice:

\(\vee,\wedge:L^2 o L\) are bothoperator on \(L\) \((L,\vee,\wedge)\) is a lattice, if and onlyif the both operators suffices:

  • commutitive law
  • associative law
  • absorption law: \(x\wedge(x\veey)=x\)

we can deduce idempotent law then: \(x\wedge x=x\)

principle of duality?

\((L,\preceq)\) is a lattice, if andonly if each two elements have a supremum and a infremum suppose \(x\wedge y=x o x\preceq y\), then \((L,\preceq)\) is partially ordered

\(x\wedge y=\inf(x,y)\) \(x\vee y=\sup(x,y)\)

a lattice have a lower bound \(0\)and an upper bound \(I\)

a totally ordered set is a lattice

some examples of lattice

  • \((\mathbb{Z}^+,\mid)\) or \((\mathbb{Z}^+,\gcd,\mathrm{lcm})\)
  • \((\mathcal{P}(S),\subseteq)\) or\((\mathcal{P}(S),\cup,\cap)\)

distributive lattice

a distributive lattice satisfies:

  • distributive law: \(x\wedge (y\veez)=(x\wedge y)\vee(x\wedge z)\)

join irreducible elements

\(x\) is a join irreducibleelement(既约并元) if and only of \(x=0\) or \((x=y_1\vee y_2) o (a=x)\vee (a=y)\) \(x\) is called an atom if and only if itimmediately succeed \(0\) \(x=d_1\vee d_2\vee\cdots\vee d_n\)

complement

\(y\) is called the complement of\(x\) if:

  • \(x\vee y=I\)
  • \(x\wedge y=0\)

complement is unique if exists

a lattice is complemented if all elements in it has a complement

Order isomorphic

we says \(X_1\) is order isomorphicto \(X_2\) , written as \(X_1\cong X_2\), if there exists a bijection\(f:X_1 o X_2\) satisfies:\[x\preceq y o f(x)\preceq f(y)\wedge x||y of(x)||f(y)\]

Infinite Set

Cardinal

the Cardinality of set \(A\), denoted as \(|A|\) we says \(A\) and \(B\) are equivalent (or equinumerous) if andonly if there exists a bijection \(f:A oB\)

  • \(f_{bi}:A o B\iff \lvert A vert=\lvertB vert\)
  • \(f_{in}:A o B\iff\lvertA vert\leq\lvert B vert\)
  • \(f_{sur}:A o B\iff\lvertA vert\geq\lvert B vert\)

\(A\) is a finiteset if and only if \(\existsn\in\mathbb{N},(|\{1,2,\cdots,n\}|=|A|)\) otherwise, it is is ainfinite set

\(A\) is a countableset if and only if \(\existsS\subseteq\mathbb{N},(|S|=|A|)\) otherwise, \(A\) is a uncountableset

Cantor-Bernstein Theorem(康托-伯恩斯坦定理) \[\lvert A vert\leq\lvert B vert\wedge\lvertB vert\leq\lvert A vert\iff\lvert A vert=\lvert B vert\]

Proof: use Banach Theorem: suppose \(f:A oB, g:B o A\), \(\existsA_0,A_1,B_0,B_1(B_1=\{f(x)|x\in A_0\}\wedge A_1=\{g(x)|x\inB_0\}\) let \(f,g\) are bothinjection, we have\(f_{bi}:A_0 o B_1g_{bi}:B_0 o A_1\)

Cantor Theorem \[\lvertS vert\lt\lvert 2^S vert\]

Proof: it suffices to prove that there isn't an injection \(f:S o 2^S\) \(Z=\{x\in S\wedge x ot\in f(x)\}\) suchtechnique is called Cantor’sDiagonalization(康托对角线) it is requently used when we intendto prove a set \(S\) is uncountablesppose \(S\) is countable, then we canput all its elements \(a,b,\cdots\) ina line, then we find a way to turn them into a sequence \(a_1,a_2,\cdots,b_1,b_2,\cdots\), and weknow that an element \(z\), such that\(z_1 eq a_1,z_2 eq b_2,\cdots\) isabsent from the line

\(\lvert\mathbb{N} vert\leq\lvert\mathbb{R} vert\)\(\lvert[a,b] vert=\mathbb{R}\)先构造一个线性映射\(f:[a,b] o[-\cfrac\pi2,\cfrac\pi2],f(x)=-\cfrac\pi2\cdot\cfrac{b+a}{b-a}\)\(f\) is a bijection, \(g(x)= an x\) \(\lvert\mathbb{R}^\infty vert=\lvert\mathbb{R} vert\)\(\lvert2^{\mathbb{N}} vert=\lvert\mathbb{R} vert\)

Ordinals

Ordinals belike: \[\Phi,\{\Phi\},\{\Phi,\{\Phi\}\},\{\Phi,\{\Phi\},\{\Phi,\{\Phi\}\}\},\cdots\]Properties of ordinals: \( eta\subset\alpha\leftrightarrow eta\in\alpha\)\(S(\alpha)=\alpha\cup\{\alpha\}\) Weuse ordinals as a representation element of Isomorphism class ofwell-ordered sets. Construct a bijection between ordinals and naturalnumber: \(f:\omega o\mathbb{N}\) \[f(\Phi)=0,f(n+1)=f(n)\cup\{f(n)\}\]

Ordinal Arithmetic

limit ordinal: \(\geq\omega\)

\(\mathrm{Succ}(\alpha)=\alpha\cup\{\alpha\}\)denoted as \(\alpha+1\) \(1+\omega=2 imes\omega=\omega\) \(\omega+\omega=\omega imes2\) \(\omega imes\omega=\omega^2\) \(\omega^{\epsilon_0}=\epsilon_0\)

\(A+B\) \(A imes B\) \(A^B\)

commutative no associative yes

Hilbert's room \(\epsilon_0=\omega^{\omega^{\omega^\omega}}\)

cardinal cardinality Arithmetic \(\aleph_0\) \(2^{\aleph_0}\)

konig \(\sum<\prod\)

transfinite

Axiomatic Set Theory

Russel Paradox

  • Russell Paradox
    • \(S=\{x|x ot\in x\} o((S\in S oS ot\in S)\wedge(S ot\in S o S\in S))\)
  • Similar Paradoxes
    • Liar Paradox
    • Barber’s Paradox
    • Unexpected Hanging Paradox

class: proper class or set

  • proper class
    • is a class but not a set
    • proper class can't be element of class?
  • set
    • \(S\) is a set if and only if \(\exists x\in S,(x\cap S=\phi)\)

ZFC

  • ZFC: Zermelo-Fraenkel Axioms with Choice
  • ZF: Zermelo-Fraenkel Axioms

AC and it's Equivalentproposition

Axioms with Choice \( orall A_i,A_j\in\mathcal{S}(A_i eq A_j oA_i\cap A_j=\Phi)\), there exists a choice function \(f:\mathcal{S} o A\)

Zorn's Lemma

Principle of mathmatical induction

  • first form
    • \(A\) is a subset of \(\mathbb{N}\) with:
    • \(1\in A\)
    • \(k\in A o k+1\in A\)
  • second form
    • \(A\) is a subset of \(\mathbb{N}\) with:
    • \(1\in A\)
    • \( igwedge_{j\in\{1,2,\cdots,k\}} j\inA o k+1\in A\)
  • principle of transfinite induction
    • \(A\) is a subset of well-orderedset \(S\) with:
    • \(a_0\in A\)
    • \(a\subseteq A o a\in A\)
